summary: Email correspondence between attorneys and federal prosecutors regarding posthumous requests for disclosure in the criminal case against Jeffrey Epstein. The email chain discusses procedural matters, including handling of Touhy regulation requests and the cessation of document production due to Epstein's death and anticipated nolle prosequi order.

persons.name: Michael C. Miller
persons.context: Attorney sending requests for disclosure to prosecutors in the Epstein case and coordinating service of letters.

persons.name: Martin G. Weinberg
persons.context: Copied on email correspondence regarding disclosure requests in the Epstein case.

persons.name: Michael Scavelli
persons.context: Copied on email correspondence regarding disclosure requests in the Epstein case.

persons.name: Reid Weingarten
persons.context: Copied on email correspondence regarding disclosure requests in the Epstein case.

persons.name: Jason Meade
persons.context: Copied on email correspondence regarding disclosure requests in the Epstein case.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Deceased defendant in the criminal case United States v. Epstein, 19 Cr. 490.

connections.description: Miller is an attorney from Steptoe & Johnson LLP handling posthumous disclosure requests related to Epstein's criminal case.
Weinberg is copied on legal correspondence regarding disclosure requests in Epstein's case.
Both attorneys are involved in the same legal correspondence regarding the Epstein case.

events.title: Disclosure Requests Filed
events.description: Michael C. Miller sends requests for disclosure pursuant to DOJ Touhy regulations to prosecutors in the Epstein case.

events.title: Civil Division Email
events.description: Email sent by the Civil Division regarding handling of Touhy regulation requests.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: The document references Epstein's death as a reason for ceasing document production in the criminal case.

events.title: Anticipated Nolle Prosequi Order
events.description: Prosecutors anticipate entry of an order of nolle prosequi (declination to prosecute) following Epstein's death.

keyFacts: The criminal case is United States v. Jeffrey Epstein, 19 Cr. 490 in the Southern District of New York.
Due to Epstein's death and the anticipated nolle prosequi order, no further document productions will be made in the criminal case.
Attorneys are making posthumous requests for disclosure under the Department of Justice's Touhy regulations.
The correspondence shows coordination between defense attorneys (Steptoe & Johnson) and federal prosecutors regarding procedural matters after Epstein's death.
The document references separate service of requests on the MCC (Metropolitan Correctional Center) and the FBI.
